sub_topic: Schwarz reflection principle and its applications
message_1:
Suppose you are given an analytic function $f(z)$ defined on the upper half-plane $\mathbb{H}=\{z\in\mathbb{C}: \text{Im}(z)>0\}$, and assume that $f(z)$ satisfies the following two conditions:

1. $f(z)$ is real-valued on the real axis $\mathbb{R}$.
2. $|f(z)|\leq M$ for some constant $M>0$.

Using the Schwarz reflection principle, determine the maximum possible value of $|f(iy)|$ for $y>0$.
message_2:
To apply the Schwarz reflection principle, we first define a new function $g(z)$ on the entire complex plane as follows:

$$
g(z) = \begin{cases}
f(z) & \text{if } \text{Im}(z) > 0 \\
\overline{f(\overline{z})} & \text{if } \text{Im}(z) < 0
\end{cases}
$$

Since $f(z)$ is real-valued on the real axis, we have $f(\overline{z}) = \overline{f(z)}$ for all $z \in \mathbb{R}$. Therefore, $g(z)$ is continuous on the real axis. Moreover, $g(z)$ is analytic in both the upper and lower half-planes because $f(z)$ is analytic in the upper half-plane and its conjugate is analytic in the lower half-plane. By the Schwarz reflection principle, $g(z)$ is analytic on the entire complex plane.

Now, consider the function $h(z) = g(z)g(-z)$. This function is also analytic on the entire complex plane, and it is real-valued on the real axis since $g(z)$ and $g(-z)$ are complex conjugates for $z \in \mathbb{R}$. By the maximum modulus principle, the maximum value of $|h(z)|$ on the imaginary axis occurs at a point where $z = iy$ for some $y > 0$. Let $z_0 = iy_0$ be such a point. Then,

$$
|h(z_0)| = |g(z_0)g(-z_0)| = |f(iy_0)f(-iy_0)| = |f(iy_0)|^2.
$$

Since $|f(z)| \leq M$ for all $z \in \mathbb{H}$, we have $|f(iy_0)| \leq M$. Therefore, the maximum possible value of $|f(iy)|$ for $y > 0$ is $M$.
